Valeria et al. [19] explored the graphene-supported exhibited excellent thermal resistance and lower temperature activation, where the CeO2/graphene catalyst showed higher selectivity for H2 generation than the alumina-supported catalyst, which improved the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Cahyana et al. [20] aimed to synthesize the spirooxindole derivative compounds using Fe3O4/graphene oxide (GO) nanocomposite as the catalyst, where SEM-EDX micrograph supported by TEM image indicated that the Fe3O4 nanoparticles in the composite had excellent dispersibility which were attributable to the existence of the GO sheets.This work is financially supported by the Major Scientific and Technological Innovation Project of Shandong Province, China (2019JZZY020305). In this paper, the mechanism of formaldehyde oxidation by the doped carbon-based single atom catalysts, mainly including Fe/DV-N4, Co/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4, is investigated by density functional theory (DFT). The Fe-doped system shows the strongest adsorption to formaldehyde, which is followed by Pd. The molecular dynamics method is used to simulate the kinetic process of formaldehyde adsorption on the surfaces of the three catalysts at different temperatures, where the adsorption energy, radial distribution function (RDF) and diffusion coefficient are analyzed. The optimum adsorption temperature of formaldehyde in both the Fe and Co systems is 500 K, which is 300 K in the Pd system. The oxidation mechanism of formaldehyde on the Fe/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4 surfaces is studied based on the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. The reaction path is searched and the energy distribution is determined, where the heat released is mainly from the dehydrogenation of formaldehyde, and the highest energy barrier is 2.63 eV in the Fe/DV-N4 system. However, the maximum energy barrier of the pathway is 6.08 eV in the Pd/DV-N4 system. Thus, the Fe/DV-N4 shows a higher catalytic activity for formaldehyde oxidation due to a smaller energy barrier. Introduction Formaldehyde (HCHO) is a common indoor pollutant, which seriously threatens the human health [1]. According to the World Health Organization's International Agency for Research on Cancer, formaldehyde is listed as a carcinogen [2]. Long time exposure to formaldehyde can cause respiratory and nervous system diseases [3]. In recent years, how to efficiently and cleanly remove formaldehyde has become an issue of the widespread public concern, among which the catalytic oxidation method gains the advantages of high efficiency and no secondary pollution [4,5]. The catalysts with strong capability can improve the catalytic efficiency, such as the noble metal catalysts and metal oxide catalysts. However, they are not suitable for the large-scale usage due to the high cost and poor performance in the low temperature range [6,7]. Single atom catalysts emerge as a hot research topic in recent years due to the great utilization of metal atoms and high catalytic activity [8,9]. Rao et al. [10] illustrated the prepared SAC-Fe/NC delivered a remarkable oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) performance, where the Fe species coordination with four pyridinic-type N atoms were demonstrated as the main contributor. Yan et al. [11] considered CO oxidation processes by DFT, where the single-atom support graphene materials exhibited better CO oxidation activities than pristine graphene, among which the Au single-atom was the active center. Ji et al. [12] demonstrated a steric hindrance effect of single atoms induced by the unique isolation of single-atom active sites to achieve a remarkable enhancement on catalytic performance in the synthesis of dimethyl carbonate. Yang et al. [13] found a single atom iron catalyst supported on a single-vacancy (SV) graphene-based substrate (Fe/SV) may be a promising catalyst for NO oxidation due to its high selectivity and high catalytic activity. Yang et al. [14] applied four kinds of graphene-based single atom iron catalysts (FeSA/GS) for catalytic oxidation of Hg0 by O2, where the single atom iron catalyst supported with double vacancy doped four N atoms graphene-based substrate had the highest catalytic activity. Single atom iron catalysts have better redox capacity due to higher active sites. Liu et al. [15] introduced FeN3-graphene as a novel catalyst to oxidatively degrade HCHO into nontoxic H2O and CO2, where the minimum activation energy was 0.95 eV and the product needed only 0.89 eV to desorb from the catalyst surface, indicating that the catalyst has potential for practical application. Yang et al. [16] firstly came up with a single atom iron coordinated with four N atoms (Fe1 N4) as a novel low-temperature NH3-SCR catalyst due to its high coordination unsaturation and safety, where the fast oxidation of NO on Fe1 N4 catalyst significantly promoted the reaction rate of NH3-SCR. Yang et al. [17] proposed a directly catalytic reduction of NO without ammonia injection by monovacancy graphene-based single atom iron catalyst (Fe/MG), where Fe/MG was suggested to be a novel catalyst for NO reduction without NH3 based on the thermodynamic and kinetic performances of Fe/MG in NO reduction. Meanwhile, graphenes show the large specific surface area and strong thermal conductivity, etc., to gain the potential as ideal catalyst carrier [18]. Valeria et al. [19] explored the graphene-supported exhibited excellent thermal resistance and lower temperature activation, where the CeO2/graphene catalyst showed higher selectivity for H2 generation than the alumina-supported catalyst, which improved the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Cahyana et al. [20] aimed to synthesize the spirooxindole derivative compounds using Fe3O4/graphene oxide (GO) nanocomposite as the catalyst, where SEM-EDX micrograph supported by TEM image indicated that the Fe3O4 nanoparticles in the composite had excellent dispersibility which were attributable to the existence of the GO sheets. The existing studies show that the structure of graphenes doped with metal atoms is more stable [21,22]. Guo et al. [23] investigated the oxidation of formaldehyde to CO2 and H2O on the Fe-doped defective graphene through the first-principle calculation, where Fe atoms stably withstood the interference from the reaction environment and effectively catalyzed the reaction between the co-adsorbed O2 and formaldehyde. Zhou et al. [24] studied the adsorption of H2CO molecules on the Co-doped Stone-Wales defective graphene by density functional theory (DFT), where the adsorption of H2CO showed the weak effect on the electronic conductance of Co-doped defective graphene. Chao et al. [25] successfully doped Pd nanoparticles in the porous graphene, where the catalyst exhibited the remarkable electrocatalytic activity and excellent cycling stability. In addition, the introduction of N atoms into the vacancy defects of carbon materials guarantees the doped metal atoms more stable [26,27]. Chen et al. [28] found the surface lattice oxygen of MnO2 was activated by nitrogen-doping, where carbon was doped with nitrogen to promote electron transfer and accelerate the HCHO oxidation process. Lin et al. [29] introduced the external N as an electron acceptor near FeN4 to modulate its charge distribution and enhance the ORR activity, where the introduction of PN greatly enhanced the electron distribution and local electric field on the Fe sites. However, the use of density functional theory to study the formaldehyde oxidation mechanism on the doped carbon-based single atom catalysts is rarely reported. In this work, the DFT calculation is used to reveal the mechanism of Fe, Co and Pd co-doped carbon-based single atom catalysts with N on the catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde. At the same time, molecular dynamics (MD) is conducted to simulate the kinetic process of formaldehyde adsorption on the catalyst surfaces in the temperature range of 300 to 800 K. Then the optimal adsorption temperature of each system is screened out, where the catalyst with the high catalytic activity is selected. Further, the reaction pathway of formaldehyde oxidation is proposed to provide a theoretical basis for the efficient catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde. 2 Models and computational methodology 2.1 Model selection In this paper, a 4 × 4 graphene unit cell is used as a catalyst carrier to investigate the Fe, Co, and Pd-doped double vacancy graphene, where three catalyst models are subsequently established. As shown in Fig. 1 , the metal atoms of these three catalysts are above the graphene plane and the vertical heights of all are 0 Å, which are consistent with the experimental values to prove the rationality of the catalyst models [30,31]. In addition, a vacuum layer with a thickness of 15 Å is built to ensure the negligible interactions between the mirror images. 2.2 Calculation methods The DFT calculations of the formaldehyde adsorption are performed by the CASTEP module, where all calculations are spin-unconstrained without setting any symmetry constraints. The generalized gradient approximation of Perdew, Burke and Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) is used to describe the electron exchange and associations [32,33]. To solve the interaction between valence electrons and ion nuclei, the electron wave function is expanded in a plane-wave basis set with a cutoff energy of 400 eV [34]. Meanwhile, a 7 × 7 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grid is used for Brillouin zone sampling, which is the same as Song et al. [35] and Liu et al. [22]. The convergence criteria, energy, maximum displacement and maximum force of the self consistent field (SCF) are set to be 2.0 × 10–6 eV/atom, 2.0 × 10–5 eV/atom, 2.0 × 10–3 Å and 0.05 eV/Å, respectively [36]. After the geometry optimization, the adsorption model of the formaldehyde molecule on graphene is obtained to be further used for molecular dynamics calculation. The molecular dynamics simulation is fulfilled by the Forcite module, where the atom based type summation method for electrostatic interactions is used with a truncation radius of 12.5 Å. The Nose thermostat is selected to perform the calculation of 5 ps in the canonical (NVT) ensemble, which is necessary to control the temperature by adjusting the speed or kinetic energy. Meanwhile, choose universal force field to calculate potential energy. The kinetic calculation step is set as 1.0 fs, and the total number of steps is 1500 steps [37,38]. The doping binding energy (E b) of the catalyst formed by the combination of defective graphene and metal is calculated by Eq. (1), where larger value means more stable of the catalyst structure [39]. (1) E b = E c a t − E M − E s u b Where, E b, E cat, E M and E sub are the binding energy, the energy of the catalyst after binding, the energy of the dopant atom and the energy of the substrate before binding, eV. To measure the stability of doped atom migration, the energy barrier (E ba) is calculated, according to the following equation: (2) E b a = E T S − E I Where, E TS is the total energy of the transition state configuration and E I is the total energy of the initial configuration, eV. The adsorption energy (Eq. (3)) is used to evaluate the adsorption stability of the gas molecule on surface of the doped graphene catalysts, where a negative Ead value signals an exothermic adsorption process. Besides, a larger absolute value of Ead indicates a larger reaction exotherm, a stronger adsorption and a more stable adsorption system [40]. (3) E a d = E s y s − ( E a d s + E s u r ) Where, E ad, E sur, E ads and E sys are the adsorption energy, the energy of the substrate, the energy of the adsorbed substance and the energy of the adsorption system, eV. The Mulliken charge transfer, ΔQ, (Eq. (4)) between the dopant atoms of the catalyst after the adsorbed species and the dopant atoms of the catalyst before the adsorbate is defined to analyze the variation of the charge amount [41]. (4) Δ Q = Q a d − Q i s o Where, Q ad and Q isoare the doping atomic charge after the catalyst adsorbs formaldehyde and the doping atomic charge before the catalyst adsorbs formaldehyde, e. To study the effect of temperature, Eq. (5) is used to calculate the heat of reaction in Gibbs free energy (∆G). (5) Δ G = G F − G I Where G F is the Gibbs free energy of the final state and G I is the Gibbs free energy of the initial state, J/mol. The Gibbs free energies of gasses and solids (G g, G s) are calculated by Eq. (6) and Eq. (7), respectively. (6) G g = E + Z P E + R T − T S (7) G s = E + Z P E − T S Where, E (eV), ZPE (J/mol), R (J/mol·k), T (K) and S (J/mol·k) are the total energy in ground state obtained from self-consistent field calculation, the zero point energy, gas constant, temperature and system entropy. When the kinetic analysis of the reaction process is carried out, the diffusion coefficient D of the atoms is calculated according to Eq. (8) [42]. (8) D = 1 6 L im t → ∞ d d t ∑ i n { | R i ( t ) − R i ( 0 ) | 2 } Where, Ri(t), Ri(0) and D are the position of the i atom at time t, the initial position and the diffusion coefficient. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Doped models The calculation models are shown in Fig. 1, where the bond lengths, vertical heights of metal atoms, doping binding energies and the energy barriers of each model are correspondingly listed in Table 1 . The doping binding energies of all the three atoms are negative to reveal an exothermic process of the doping process. Besides, the structure of Co/DV-N4 catalyst is the most stable due to the largest absolute value of the Co-doped binding energy and the energy barrier. The vertical heights of all the three metal atoms above the graphene plane are 0 Å. The Fe-N bond, which is formed by intercalation of the Fe atom into the double vacancies of the catalyst, shows the different lengths from 1.895 to 1.906 Å, while the four M-N bonds formed by the double vacancies of Co and Pd atoms inserted into the catalyst are of the equal length. 3.2 Adsorption of HCHO on the surface of doped catalysts In this section, the adsorption performances of HCHO on Fe/DV-N4, Co/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4 catalysts are studied. After the geometry optimization, the models are displayed in Fig. 2 . The parameters of the adsorption energy, Mulliken charge, bond length and the change in the vertical height of metal atoms are listed in Table 2 . It is easily found that HCHO is adsorbed on the dopant metal atoms, where the change in the vertical height of the Fe atom above the graphene plane is 0.432 Å and the Fe-N distance is greatly increased after adsorption. However, the CH bond length of the formaldehyde molecule varies insignificantly and the C=O bond length is developed from 1.211 to 1.306 Å due to the activation of the formaldehyde molecule. Meanwhile, the vertical height of the Co atom is extended to 0.411 Å with the Co-N distance highly increased to 1.919 Å, while the vertical height of the Pd atom below the graphene plane changes by 0.108 Å with the Pd-N distance that alters unapparently. Besides, the CH bond length of the formaldehyde molecule decreases slightly and the C=O bond length increases marginally. All the adsorption energies of the formaldehyde molecule on the surfaces of the three catalysts are negative to announce to be exothermic of the adsorption process. The absolute value of the adsorption energy of Fe/DV-N4 is the largest to show that the most stability of its adsorption system. All the metal atomic charge transfer amount of the three systems is small, among which the charge transfer amount of Fe atom is −0.018 e as the catalyst loses electrons and the formaldehyde molecule gains electrons during the adsorption process. Whereas the Co atom with 0.006 e of the charge transfer amount hints that the electrons are transferred from the gas molecule to the catalyst in the adsorption system, though the amount is minute. Pd atomic charge transfer amount is −0.015 e, where more charge transfer means larger adsorption energy to be consistent with the adsorption energy result. To deeply understand the influence of the HCHO adsorption, the electron density differences in Fig. 3 and partial density of states (PDOS) of the three catalysts in Fig. 4 are obtained. Meanwhile, the PDOS of HCHO and doped metal atoms before and after adsorption are analyzed to explain the electron rearrangement. In Fig. 3, the charge accumulation and depletion regions are shown in blue and red color, respectively, and the white color pinpoints the region with hardly no variation in the electron density [43,44]. Charge consumption occurs in vicinity of the Fe and Pd atomic sites as the adsorption of HCHO leads to the redistribution of the surface charge on the catalyst, which is also observed around the HCHO molecule. While in the Co/DV-N4 system, in vicinity of the Co atom, charge accumulation can be found. However, the color change is inapparent, arguing that the Co/DV-N4 cluster shows a weak charge transfer with HCHO, which is in agreement with the previous Mulliken charge calculations. As seen from Fig. 4 of the Fe-doped system, the s orbital of HCHO has a maximum value at -11 eV before adsorption while the p orbital is at -1.5 eV. After adsorption, the formaldehyde molecule curves are shifted to the right as a whole for gaining electrons. The hybridization and overlap between the Fe atom and HCHO demonstrate a strong charge transfer, which is in accordance with the electron density difference analysis. The displacement of the p orbital is obvious as the p orbital plays a major role in the adsorption process. In Fig. 4(a), the 2p orbit of HCHO overlaps with the 3d orbit of Fe atom at the Fermi level, implying that the Fe atom forms the bond with the HCHO. The peaks of s, p and d orbitals before the Fe atom adsorption are about 0.12 eV, 0.11 eV and 3.93 eV, respectively. The peak of the s orbital and the peak shape near the Fermi level both decrease significantly after adsorption. Besides, the Fe-d orbital peaks in the Fermi level are combined into one peak. Based on the above analysis, the dopant of Fe can improve the HCHO adsorption capacity of the catalyst surface. The PDOS of HCHO before and after adsorption are firstly considered in the Co-doped system. The peaks of the s and p orbitals are increased markedly after adsorption and most of the s orbitals are on the left side of the Fermi level. The peaks of s and p orbitals before adsorption are about 1.64 and 1.7 eV. The PDOS of Co atom before and after adsorption is subsequently compared, where the peaks of all the orbitals in the valence band are changed obviously after adsorption. The s-orbital peak increases after adsorption, which is almost to the left of the Fermi energy level. The displacement of the Co atom is short by reason of the weak adsorption energy, which is consistent with the energy of Ead . Comparing Fig. 4 (a) and (b), the overlap of the Fe atom and HCHO orbits is more obvious to show the intense interaction between the Fe atom and HCHO. To explain the interaction between the formaldehyde molecule and the Pd/DV-N4 surface, the PDOS of HCHO and Pd atom are analyzed and shown in Fig. 4(c). The s and p orbital peaks of HCHO are 2.73 and 2.58 eV before adsorption, both of which are increased after adsorption. The two orbital peaks of the s orbital merge into one peak at -21.8 eV energy and the multiple orbital peaks merge into two peaks at -6.78 eV energy. Similarly, the p orbital of HCHO in the adsorbed phase is increased in the peak intensity and shifted towards the higher energy level. The adsorption of HCHO increases the density of the occupied states below the Fermi level, which also suggests that electrons are transferred from the Pd atom to the HCHO. Before the adsorption of the Pd atom, the peaks of the s, p and d orbitals are about 0.08 eV, 0.11 eV and 3.11 eV, respectively. The p orbital of the Pd atom in the adsorbed phase shows a decreased intensity of the peaks and moves to the lower energy level, while the s orbital forms a sharp peak near the Fermi level which increases sharply. In order to further investigate the interaction and bonding types between the formaldehyde molecule and catalysts, the Electron Localization Function (ELF) of the three adsorption systems are analyzed, as shown in Fig. 5 . ELF ranges between 0 and 1 and can give additional information on the location and the strength of the bonds. When ELF>0.5, the electron motion is fixed in the space region to form a fixed domain. On the contrary, it indicates that the electrons are free in this space region, forming an outlying domain [45]. The blue area with a small ELF value and the red region with a large ELF value are marked in Fig. 5. Three tangent planes are created separately to facilitate the observation of ELF values. In the Fe/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4 systems, the ELF values between the adjacent CC and CN on the graphene substrate are greater than 0.5. The presences of CC and CN bonds confirm partially covalent bonds. Near Fe and Pd atoms that show minute values of ELF correspond to low electron localization. The ionic bonds between Fe-N and Pd-N are expected to be strong localized bonds, which are supported by the ELF maps. Besides, near the HCHO side with greater than 0.5 value presents that the bonds formed between Fe atom and Pd atom with the formaldehyde molecule are both ionic bonds, which belong to chemical adsorption. The regions around adjacent CC and CN on the graphene substrate in the Co/DV-N4 system are characterized by high values of electron localization. There are more reddish parts, showing that the strength of CC and CN covalent bonds formed after Co doping increases that leads to create a stable catalyst structure, which is consistent with the above calculation results of doping energy. With a combination of highly localized (red) regions surrounded by lower electron concentration (blue) regions in the three systems, thus CH and C=O of the HCHO are constructed strong covalent bonds. 3.3 Adsorption of O2 on the surface of doped catalysts In this section, the adsorption characteristics of O2 on the surfaces of three catalysts are investigated. The possible adsorption configurations are modeled and optimized to obtain the structures shown in Fig. 6 . The parameters of the adsorption energy, bond length and distance between oxygen atom and dopant metal atoms are listed in Table 3 . From the Fig. 6, it is easily found that O2 is adsorbed vertically on the Fe and Co atoms, while obliques adsorption on the surface of Pd/DV-N4 catalyst. All the adsorption energies of the oxygen molecule on the surfaces of the three catalysts are negative to announce to be exothermic of the adsorption process. The absolute value of the adsorption energy of Fe/DV-N4 is the largest to show that the most stability of its adsorption system. The Fe-N distance is greatly increased after adsorption, while Pd-N is decreased. The OO bond length is developed from 1.243 Å to 1.270 Å in the Fe-doped system, which means O2 is activated during the adsorption process. Compared with the data in Table 2, the oxygen adsorption energies of Fe and Co systems are both greater than that of formaldehyde, while the adsorption energies of Pd systems are similar. The results show that in the process of formaldehyde oxidation, oxygen first occupies the active site of the Fe/DV-N4 and Co/DV-N4 catalyst. Whereas both formaldehyde and oxygen have the equal probability to occupy the active sites first in Pd-doped system. However, there is no co-adsorption structure of the three catalysts. 3.4 Kinetic analysis The adsorption of HCHO on the three catalyst surfaces at the different temperatures is investigated using molecular dynamics simulation methods. Then the most suitable adsorption temperature is selected for further research according to the influence of the three catalysts. The effects of different temperatures on the adsorption energy at the three systems are analyzed. After the geometry optimization, the adsorption energies of the doped systems are depicted in Fig. 7 . From the picture, it is easy to see that the adsorption energy of formaldehyde on Fe/DV-N4 is greater than that on Co/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4 at all temperatures simulated. When the temperature up to 500 K, the adsorption energy of Fe/DV-N4 is the largest. As for the doping of the Co atom, the adsorption energy is performed poorly at the temperatures from 300 to 800 K, which is relatively good at 500 K. The calculation results show that after doped with the Pd atom, the HCHO chemisorption on the doped surface becomes strongest at 300 K, where the adsorption system is the most stable. To understand the thermodynamic properties of the HCHO oxidation reaction, the reaction energies expressed in Gibbs free energy at temperatures from 300 to 800 K are calculated, as shown in Fig. 8 . The figure clearly shows that the reaction energy of the HCHO oxidation reaction is less than 0 in the studied temperature range, indicating that the reaction can proceed spontaneously. The reaction energy rises with the increase of temperature, which reveals the growth of reaction temperature has an inhibitory effect on the spontaneity of formaldehyde oxidation reaction. As shown in Fig. 9 , the Gibbs free energies of HCHO at different temperatures are recalculated to study the desorption temperature of HCHO. From Fig. 9, it can be seen that the ΔGad of the three catalysts are all less than zero at room temperature (300 K), revealing that the adsorption of HCHO can occur spontaneously. A negative ΔGad value shows stable adsorption, while the adsorption is unstable if the value is positive. The desorption temperature determines the operating economy of the catalyst, where a higher desorption temperature means more energy. Based on the above discussion, we can conclude that Fe/DV-N4 has essential properties as a catalyst from the perspectives of economy and environmental protection, which suggests that Fe/DV-N4 is a promising formaldehyde removal material. The radical distribution function (RDF) diagrams between the formaldehyde molecule and doped atoms (shown in Fig. 10 ), which is for the further analysis of the motion and structural changes of the formaldehyde molecule during adsorption under different working conditions, are drawn [46]. All the curves in the Fe/DV-N4 system, at 300–800 K, of radial distribution functions are the same when the first peak is around 2 Å. It is pointed out that the shortest distance between the formaldehyde molecule and the Fe atom is about 2 Å, which is close to the C-Fe bond length previously analyzed. Compared with the temperatures of 500 K, 600 K and 800 K, the peaks are the highest around 2 Å at the rest of the simulated temperatures. The highest peak of 500 K and 600 K appears in 2.5 Å, and that of 800 K appears in 4.5 Å which illustrates the occurrence of strong interactions. From Fig. 10, it is found that the peaks of the radial distribution function show a trend from high to low at all temperatures simulated, which suggests that the formaldehyde molecule gradually moves away from the Fe atom. In the Co/DV-N4 system, the first peak position of all the curves is approximately at 2.2 Å, which is consistent with the CCo bond length analysis. Comparison with the peak values at 300–500 K shows that the peaks at 2.2 Å at 600 K and 800 K are maximum. It can be found intuitively that as the peak diffuses into multiple peaks at 3.9 Å at 300 K, an amorphous structure is generated at this time. From Fig. 10, it is obtained that the peaks of the radial distribution function decrease both at 600 K and 800 K, and the peak shapes are widened after absorbing, which reveal the variations of the internal structure of Co/DV-N4 and production of the lattice distortion. The curves in the Pd doped system at each simulated temperature are different, displaying that the temperature impacts greatly on the adsorption of formaldehyde. The first peak positions at the simulated temperatures are all located between 2 Å and 3 Å. Combining these results with the finding that the radial distribution function peak shapes tend to be low shows that the formaldehyde molecule constantly moves away from the Pd atom. In general, all the curves gradually converge to 1 with the growth of r. The size of the ordered cast becomes significantly large, meaning that the structures of the three catalyst models change [47]. Using the mean square displacement and diffusion coefficient (D) of the formaldehyde molecule in three catalyst systems at 300–800 K, the influencing characteristics of temperature on diffusion can be determined, where a larger diffusion coefficient proves a higher diffusion capacity [48]. Fig. 11 shows the mean square displacement curves of the formaldehyde molecule after adsorption, and the diffusion coefficients of each model are listed in Table 4 . Seeing from the figure, the diffusion coefficient reaches it is maximum at 800 K in the Fe system, while that of the formaldehyde molecule is very small in the low temperature stage (300–400 K). With the increase of temperature, the diffusion coefficient goes up significantly, which raises tenfold at 800 K. Satisfactory results cannot be achieved at a reaction temperature of 400 K with the diffusion coefficient of Co system, which is consistent with the adsorption energy result. The diffusion at 300 K, 500 K and 700 K of 2.847 × 10–20 m2 s–1, 3.084 × 10–20 m2 s–1 and 3.290 × 10–20 m2 s–1, respectively, can be described as weak diffusion. It can be seen from Fig. 11 that the curve slope of the Co system is relatively large at 800 K during 2 to 4 ps. This is because the formaldehyde molecule interacts strongly with the Co atom at this time, which is coherent with the analysis of the aforementioned radial distribution function diagrams. The diffusion coefficients of the Pd system at the simulated temperatures with a tendency to increase first and then decrease are broadly greater than those of the Fe system, and mostly higher than those of the Co system. From Table 4, it is demonstrated that the diffusion coefficients reach the maximum at 500 K and minimum at 600 K. Various indications show that the temperature has an important effect on the diffusion of the formaldehyde molecule in the three doping systems. 3.5 Formaldehyde catalytic oxidation reaction path analysis According to the adsorption results above, Fe/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4 with acceptable performance are selected as the objects of study. It is considered that the oxidation reaction of the formaldehyde molecule on these two catalysts follow the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. Selecting the Fe/DV-N4 model at 500 K, the intermediates, transition states and final configurations during the oxidation of formaldehyde and the energy of each reaction step are shown in Fig. 12 . In order to understand the oxidation reaction mechanism of formaldehyde more clearly, Scheme 1 is made. Firstly, the formaldehyde molecule is chemically adsorbed on the surface of Fe/DV-N4 as the initial configuration IM1 with O2. In IM1, HCHO is adsorbed on the Fe atom in the form of Fe-O and Fe-C bonds with the lengths of 1.961 Å and 2.021 Å, respectively. Subsequently, the two O atoms form bonds with the C atom of the formaldehyde molecule and the Fe atom of the catalyst, respectively. The formation of CO-O-Fe-O ring (IM2) with OO bond length changes as follows: 1.260 Å (IM1)→1.286 Å (TS1)→1.332 Å (IM2). In this process, the energy barrier to generate IM2 through TS1 is 0.85 eV and the reaction heat is 0.22 eV. Then the OO structure on the catalyst is destroyed. The O bonded to the Fe atom combines with the H of HCHO to form the conformation IM3. The OH bond length is reduced from 1.409 Å (TS2) to 1.008 Å (IM3), during which 1.56 eV reaction heat is needed. The process overcomes the energy barrier of 2.63 eV. At last, O-Fe bonds are cracked and the H atom is desorbed to produce H2O and CO2 with the energy barrier of 0.25 eV, releasing the energy of 1.96 eV. From Fig. 12, it can be further analyzed that the heat released from the oxidation of the formaldehyde molecule mainly comes from the steps of IM1→IM2 and IM3→FS. To choose the Pd/DV-N4 model at 300 K, the intermediates, transition states and final configurations during the oxidation of formaldehyde and the energy of each reaction step are plotted in Fig. 13 . As given in Scheme 2 , the illustration of reaction mechanism about catalytic oxidation of HCHO over Pd/DV-N4 is drawn. First of all, the O2 molecule is vertically chemisorbed on the surface of Pd/DV-N4, forming the initial configuration IM1 with HCHO, in which O2 is adsorbed as a Pd-O bond over the Pd atom with a bond length of 2.364 Å. Subsequently, the O atom from HCHO migrates to the Pd atom formed the O-Pd bond to establish IM2. The distance between the migrated O and Pd is shortened from 2.294 Å to 2.128 Å. The OO bond length changes as follows: 1.251 Å (IM1)→1.249 Å (TS1)→1.246 Å (IM2), which tends to decrease during this process with the energy barrier of 0.42 eV. This is an exothermic process which releases 0.06 eV of heat. Then the co-adsorbed HCHO attracts one O atom of the O2 molecule so that the OO bond is broken, resulting in the formation of a OH bond, as shown by IM3. The change in bond length between Pd and O atom in HCHO molecule is 2.128 Å (IM2)→2.929 Å (TS2)→2.130 Å (IM3). Whereas the bond length change between Pd and O atom in the O2 molecule is 2.000 Å (IM2)→2.374 Å (TS2)→2.277 Å (IM3), which shows a trend of increasing first and then decreasing. The reaction heat is 3.52 eV with the energy barrier of 2.13 eV. Finally, the other H atom in the HCHO molecule detaches and bonds with the O atom in the O2 molecule, forming H2O and CO2 and leaving the catalyst surface. The process overcomes the 6.08 eV energy barrier to form the final conformation FS and releases the energy of 2.99 eV. It can be found from Fig. 13 that the heat released from the oxidation of HCHO molecule mainly comes from the step of IM2→IM3. The energy barrier values and product desorption energy of Fe/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4 studied in this paper and other previous catalysts are listed in Table 5 . It can be easily seen that HCHO has the smallest oxidation reaction energy barrier and the desorption energy of the product on the Fe/DV-N4 surface by comparison, which is a promising catalyst. 4 Conclusions The adsorption of HCHO by the doped catalysts, mainly including Fe/DV-N4, Co/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4, was systematically studied by the density functional theory. Besides, the molecular dynamics method was used to explore the formaldehyde adsorption in the temperature range of 300–800 K. Both optimal temperature and excellent adsorption system were choosing, which are designed to carry out further research on the catalytic oxidation process of formaldehyde. Conclusions can be summarized as following: None of the three catalysts have significant Δh values after adsorbing HCHO which represent they are all stable during the adsorption process. According to the results of doping energy, Co/DV-N4 has the best stability, followed by Fe/DV-N4. Compared with the Co and Pd doped systems, Fe/DV-N4 has the best adsorption performance, where the adsorption process releases heat and the catalyst loses electrons. Dynamics simulations are combined with adsorption energy and diffusion coefficient at the simulated temperature to analysis comprehensively. The optimal adsorption temperatures for Fe/DV-N4, Co/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4 are 500 K, 500 K and 300 K, respectively. The oxidation mechanism of HCHO on the surface of Co/DV-N4 system is not considered in this study due to the unsatisfactory adsorption, while that of the other two systems follows the E-R mechanism. In the Fe/DV-N4 system, the bonding stage overcomes an energy barrier of 0.85 eV. The heat released by the reaction mainly comes from the dehydrogenation reaction of HCHO with a maximum energy barrier of 2.63 eV. The activation energy of formaldehyde oxidation reaction is 0.42 eV to 6.08 eV in the Pd/DV-N4 system. It can be concluded that Fe/DV-N4 has higher catalytic activity for HCHO oxidation on the ground of the smaller energy barrier on the doped surface, which means that the catalyst is a promising catalyst with a predictable performance. Further, the work provides theoretical basis for efficient catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, the mechanism of formaldehyde oxidation by the doped carbon-based single atom catalysts, mainly including Fe/DV-N4, Co/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4, is investigated by density functional theory (DFT). The Fe-doped system shows the strongest adsorption to formaldehyde, which is followed by Pd. The molecular dynamics method is used to simulate the kinetic process of formaldehyde adsorption on the surfaces of the three catalysts at different temperatures, where the adsorption energy, radial distribution function (RDF) and diffusion coefficient are analyzed. The optimum adsorption temperature of formaldehyde in both the Fe and Co systems is 500 K, which is 300 K in the Pd system. The oxidation mechanism of formaldehyde on the Fe/DV-N4 and Pd/DV-N4 surfaces is studied based on the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. The reaction path is searched and the energy distribution is determined, where the heat released is mainly from the dehydrogenation of formaldehyde, and the highest energy barrier is 2.63 eV in the Fe/DV-N4 system. However, the maximum energy barrier of the pathway is 6.08 eV in the Pd/DV-N4 system. Thus, the Fe/DV-N4 shows a higher catalytic activity for formaldehyde oxidation due to a smaller energy barrier.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanism of formaldehyde oxidation catalyzed by doped graphene single atom catalysts: Density functional theory study
